page.title: 03ECOLOGY SCRAPTOFT THURNBY
page.content: The valley itself is rolling farmland typical of the high parts of east Leicestershire. It is a mixture of arable land and intensively managed grassland.There are few trees except a few copses and spinneys but the hedges which separate the fields do include large trees.Unfortunately Dutch Elm disease has destroyed over 70% of trees in the area.The hedges which are laid back in traditional Leicestershire manner form an impenetrable barrier for animals and humans alike, being formed of mainly of hawthorn.Other trees in the hedges are oak, ash, elder and rowan.The dismantled railway has in the last twenty years become overgrown and trees and shrubs have established themselves along it.The wooded areas and hedges provide a good envionment for wildlife.
